title: The Man Who Didnâ€™t Look Right
summary: Much of human behavior is unconscious and driven by subtle cues. We often act without thinking because habits automate our actions. To change habits, we must become aware of these cues by pointing-and-calling, habit tracking, and environmental design.
keyIdeas: Our brains automate patterns to conserve energy.
We often act without conscious awareness.
Environment influences behavior more than motivation.
Awareness is the first step in breaking bad habits.
examples: Train operators shouting actions aloud reduce mistakes.
Tracking spending reveals unconscious spending patterns.
exercises: Perform a habit audit: list your daily habits as 'positive,' 'negative,' or 'neutral.'
Try pointing-and-calling for one routine today.
reflections: Which unconscious behaviors run most of your day?
What habit becomes easier once you increase awareness?
